response: Landlords must keep premises habitable and follow due process for eviction; tenants must pay rent on time and avoid damage. Written rental agreements and receipts reduce disputes.
Rent increases usually require advance written notice and must respect local rent-control or state rules. Sudden or retrospective hikes are commonly restricted.
Security deposits should be returned after lawful deductions for unpaid rent or documented damage. Keep move‑in photos and a handover checklist to avoid disputes.
Eviction typically requires proper notice and, if contested, a court order. Self‑help lockouts or cutting utilities are often unlawful; tenants may seek immediate relief.
Landlords generally handle structural repairs and essential services; tenants should promptly notify issues in writing and allow access for fixes.
Subletting or adding roommates often needs landlord consent per the lease. Unauthorized subletting can be a ground for eviction.
Traffic fines can be paid or contested through the designated portal or local traffic court. Deadlines are short; inaction can add penalties or lead to license issues.
Keep your driving licence and registration valid; repeated or major violations can trigger suspension. You usually have a right to a hearing or appeal.
After an accident, prioritize safety, inform police/insurer promptly, and preserve evidence. Third‑party liability is mandatory; claim windows are time‑bound.
A simple contract needs a clear offer, acceptance, and consideration. Put important terms in writing and keep dated copies signed by all parties.
Electronic signatures can bind parties if intent and consent are clear. Keep evidence of the signing flow (emails, timestamps, IP/OTP logs).
If a product or service is defective or deficient, document the issue and contact the seller or service provider in writing. Escalate to consumer authorities if unresolved.
For service deficiencies, demand a written fix deadline and keep records. If unmet, you may seek a refund, compensation, or file a consumer complaint.
Dispute unauthorized or failed transactions with your bank quickly and in writing. Provide receipts, screenshots, and merchant responses as evidence.
Read probation terms, role, pay, and notice periods carefully before joining. Keep a signed copy of the final offer and any amendments.
Notice periods should follow the contract or policy. Request a relieving letter and full‑and‑final settlement; challenge unlawful deductions or abrupt terminations in writing.
Escalate salary delays to HR in writing and keep payslips and offer letters. Persistent non‑payment can be escalated to labour authorities or legal notice.
Workplaces must provide a safe environment and a formal complaint route. Report to the Internal Complaints Committee or designated authority and preserve evidence.
NDAs protect confidential information. Post‑employment non‑compete terms are often narrowly enforceable; focus on confidentiality and non‑solicitation obligations.
Confirm your eligibility for gratuity and social‑security benefits; ensure correct KYC and bank details to avoid delays in withdrawal or settlement.
Leave and overtime rules depend on policy and local law. Track hours and get approvals in writing to avoid later disputes.
Marriage and divorce procedures vary by personal and local law. Document finances and custody arrangements early; consider mediation for settlements.
Courts consider income, needs, and dependents when awarding support. Keep evidence of earnings and expenses to substantiate claims or defenses.
You can seek immediate protection orders, residence relief, and financial support. Record incidents, save messages, and contact authorities or helplines promptly.
Courts focus on the child’s best interests. Draft practical parenting plans covering schooling, health, and holidays.
Adoption requires approvals through authorized channels and due diligence on documents. Avoid informal transfers; they can create long‑term legal issues.
Verify title, encumbrances, and approvals before paying. Use a written agreement, staged payments, and safeguard originals until registration completes.
For delayed possession, notify the builder in writing and track promised dates. Consumer and real‑estate regulators may allow refunds, interest, or compensation.
Follow society bylaws for dues and permissions. Disputes can be raised before the managing committee and, if needed, local authorities or forums.
After purchase or inheritance, update records (mutation) and pay property tax on time. Keep receipts and obtain an encumbrance certificate when needed.
If a will exists, probate or validation may be required. Without a will, succession follows applicable personal law; collect legal‑heir and asset documents early.
Serious cognizable offences can be reported for FIR registration; keep a written acknowledgement or number. Preserve evidence and witness details.
Arrested persons have rights to be informed of grounds, legal counsel, and to be produced before a magistrate within a set time. Bail depends on offence and facts.
Defamation claims require false statements that harm reputation. Truth, fair comment, and privilege are typical defenses; preserve posts and communications.
Act quickly: block accounts/cards, complain on official portals, and file a police report. Keep screenshots, transaction IDs, and timestamps as evidence.
You can usually ask organizations to correct or delete inaccurate personal data and to explain how it’s used. Withdraw consent in writing when appropriate.
Review the platform’s terms and appeal process. Submit a concise appeal with IDs and screenshots; repeated violations or chargebacks often trigger permanent bans.
Copyright protects original works automatically upon creation. Using others’ content needs permission unless a narrow legal exception applies; credit alone is not enough.
A distinctive mark identifies your goods or services. Avoid names confusingly similar to existing marks; misuse can invite objections or legal action.
Patents require novelty and inventive step. Public disclosure before filing can destroy rights; consider a confidentiality agreement when discussing ideas.
Choose a structure (sole‑prop, partnership, LLP, company) based on liability and compliance needs. Reserve the name, draft documents, and obtain required registrations.
Check sector‑specific licenses (e.g., food, trade) and tax registration requirements. Keep renewal dates and compliance calendars.
Record purchase orders and delivery proofs. For micro/small suppliers, formal mechanisms may exist to recover delayed payments with interest.
Contracts may require arbitration or encourage mediation. Early settlement can reduce time and costs; ensure the clause clearly names seat and rules.
For smaller monetary disputes, summary or simplified procedures may exist. File within limitation periods and attach key documents as exhibits.
Most claims have strict filing deadlines. Note the date of breach or discovery and act promptly; delays can forfeit rights.
Demand a written breakup and refund policy from the institution. Keep payment receipts; escalate unreasonable refusals to the regulator or ombudsman where available.
Request medical records and second opinions. Document timelines and bills; serious lapses can be pursued through consumer or other legal forums.
Read the policy exclusions and submit all required documents. Appeal denials in writing and request reasons; external grievance channels may exist.
Communicate with lenders in writing, propose restructuring if needed, and log all collection calls. Harassment or threats can be reported.
Dispute incorrect entries with the bureau and lender in writing. Keep acknowledgements; corrections can take time to reflect.
You may request information from public authorities by filing a concise application with fees where applicable. Appeals exist if you receive no response or denials.
Keep travel documents valid and truthful. Overstays or misrepresentations can cause bans; consult the relevant embassy or authority for rectification steps.
If deliveries are delayed or cancelled without refund, raise a written ticket and request timelines. Escalate to payment providers if merchants remain unresponsive.
Log a service request with a job‑sheet number and photos. If repeated failures occur, request replacement or refund per policy.
Many day‑to‑day disputes involve purchases, services, employment, or housing. Keep everything in writing, meet deadlines, and use official grievance channels.
If your issue doesn’t fit a category, write a short timeline with dates, amounts, and messages. Clear facts make it easier to find the right procedure.
